## Description

The **code** component allows you to write your own short snippets of JavaScript code, and is handy for writing quick functions or data transformations that are specific to your product or industry.
Please see the [full article](pathname:///docs/code-component-usage/) on the code component for information on when a code component is appropriate, and common use cases for a code component.

Code component steps should be succinct and integration-specific.
If the code you write could be reused in other integrations, if it needs to handle credentials, or if the code is complex enough that it would benefit from unit tests, etc., you should write a [custom component](/self-managed/composer/builder/custom-components/writing-custom-components.mdx) instead.

For some examples of code component usage, check out these quickstart guides:

- [Using a Code Component to Transform Data](/self-managed/composer/builder/custom-components/quickstarts/code-component-to-transform-data.mdx)
- [Generating a PDF with a Code Component](/self-managed/composer/builder/custom-components/quickstarts/generating-a-pdf-with-a-code-component.mdx)

## Triggers

<div id="runcodetrigger" />

### Code Block Trigger

Author and run your own code as a trigger | <small><b>key: runCodeTrigger</b></small>

<ComponentInputsTable
  inputs={[
    {
      required: true,
      comments: "The code to be executed",
      language: "javascript",
      key: "code",
      type: "code",
      default:
        '/*\n  Access config variables by name through the configVars object. e.g.\n    const apiEndpoint = `${configVars["App Base URL"]}/api`;\n\n  Access the trigger payload using the payload argument. This includes\n  headers, the body of the request, and more information about the request.\n\n  You can return string, number or complex object data. e.g.\n    return { payload: { foo: "Hello", bar: 123.45, baz: true } };\n\n  You are also able to return an optional response to the webhook caller.\n  For example, you can respond with a CSV response like the following:\n    return {\n      payload: { foo: "Hello", bar: 123.45, baz: true },\n      response: { statusCode: 200, contentType: "text/csv", body: "hello,world" },\n    }\n*/\n\nmodule.exports = async ({ logger, configVars }, payload) => {\n  const response = {\n    statusCode: 200,\n    contentType: "text/plain",\n    body: "hello",\n  };\n  return { payload, response };\n};',
      label: "Code",
    },
  ]}
/>

#### Output Example Payload

```json
{
  "payload": null
}
```

<hr className="componentActionSeparator" />

## Data Sources

<div id="runcodejsonform" />

### Code Block JSON Form

Author and run your own code as a JSON Form data source | <small><b>key: runCodeJsonForm</b></small> | <small><b>type: jsonForm</b></small>

<ComponentInputsTable
  inputs={[
    {
      required: true,
      comments: "The code to be executed",
      language: "javascript",
      key: "code",
      type: "code",
      default:
        'module.exports = async (context, { connection, contextValue }) => {\n  const schema = {\n    type: "object",\n    properties: {\n      companyName: {\n        type: "string",\n      },\n      companyDescription: {\n        type: "string",\n        description: "You can enter multiple lines here",\n      },\n      numEmployees: {\n        type: "integer",\n        description: "Include employees in all offices",\n      },\n      continent: {\n        type: "string",\n        enum: [\n          "North America",\n          "South America",\n          "Europe",\n          "Asia",\n          "Africa",\n          "Australia",\n        ],\n      },\n      biDirectionalSync: {\n        type: "boolean",\n      },\n    },\n    required: ["companyName"],\n  };\n\n  const uiSchema = {\n    type: "VerticalLayout",\n    elements: [\n      {\n        type: "Control",\n        scope: "#/properties/companyName",\n      },\n      {\n        type: "Control",\n        scope: "#/properties/companyDescription",\n        options: {\n          multi: true,\n        },\n      },\n      {\n        type: "Control",\n        label: "Employee Count",\n        scope: "#/properties/numEmployees",\n      },\n      {\n        type: "Control",\n        scope: "#/properties/continent",\n      },\n      {\n        type: "Control",\n        label: "Sync Data Bi-Directionally?",\n        scope: "#/properties/biDirectionalSync",\n      },\n    ],\n  };\n\n  const data = {\n    companyName: "Example Company",\n  };\n\n  return Promise.resolve({\n    schema,\n    uiSchema,\n    data,\n  });\n};',
      label: "Code",
    },
    {
      required: false,
      key: "connection",
      type: "connection",
      label: "Connection",
    },
    {
      required: false,
      key: "contextValue",
      type: "data",
      default: "",
      label: "Context Value",
    },
  ]}
/>

<hr className="componentActionSeparator" />

Author and run your own code as a object selection data source | <small><b>key: runCodeObjectSelection</b></small> | <small><b>type: objectSelection</b></small>

      label: "Code",
    },
    {
      required: false,

### Code Block String

Author and run your own code as a string data source | <small><b>key: runCodeString</b></small> | <small><b>type: string</b></small>

<ComponentInputsTable
  inputs={[
    {
      required: true,
      comments: "The code to be executed",
      language: "javascript",
      key: "code",
      type: "code",
      default:
        "\nmodule.exports = async (context, { connection, contextValue }) => {\n  // Random number between 1 and 100\n  const randomNumber = Math.floor(Math.random() * 100 + 1)\n\n  // Random To-Do item\n  const response = await fetch(`https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos/${randomNumber}`);\n\n  const { title } = await response.json();\n\n  return { result: title };\n};",
      label: "Code",
    },
    {
      required: false,
      key: "connection",
      type: "connection",
      label: "Connection",
    },
    {
      required: false,
      key: "contextValue",
      type: "data",
      default: "",
      label: "Context Value",
    },
  ]}

## Actions

<div id="runcode" />

### Code Block

Author and run your own code | <small><b>key: runCode</b></small>

<ComponentInputsTable
  inputs={[
    {
      required: true,
      comments: "The code to be executed",
      language: "javascript",
      key: "code",
      type: "code",
      default:
        '/*\n  Access config variables by name through the configVars object. e.g.\n    const apiEndpoint = `${configVars["App Base URL"]}/api`;\n\n  Access previous steps\' results through the stepResults object. Trigger\n  and step names are camelCased. If the step "Get Data from API" returned\n  {"foo": "bar", "baz": 123}, you could destructure that data with:\n    const { foo, baz } = stepResults.getDataFromApi.results;\n\n  You can return string, number or complex object data. e.g.\n    return { data: { foo: "Hello", bar: 123.45, baz: true } };\n*/\n\nmodule.exports = async ({ logger, configVars }, stepResults) => {\n  return { data: null };\n};\n',
      label: "Code",
    },
  ]}
/>

#### Output Example Payload

```
{
  "data": null
}
```

<hr className="componentActionSeparator" />
